page.title: 04Berwick Church: St.James
page.content: {St.James}is built largely of local materials: field flints to reduce the expense of stone from a distance, though clay tiles have replaced the original thatch. Berwick church is 75 feet long and without aisles. Its oldest feature is the{twelfth century doorway,}with carved heads supporting the beams inside. The medieval stone pulpit is one of two surviving in Wiltshire, originally entered by a staircase in the wall halfway down the nave. {Reverend Adams,}the present incumbent is extremely unusual nowadays in that although at present he covers Berwick, Stapleford and Winterbourne Stoke he uses no form of transport at all and is often to be seen walking between his parishes. {Services}are held once a fortnight.
